title: SS Geelong
text:
Geelong was a ship which owned by the <a href="Blue%20Anchor%20Line">Blue Anchor Line</a>, and, after 1910, by <a href="P%26amp%3BO%20%28company%29">P&O</a>. She was constructed in 1904 by Barclay, Curle and Co. Ltd., at <a href="Glasgow">Glasgow</a>, <a href="Scotland">Scotland</a>. When originally constructed, she had accommodation for 120 saloon and 200 third-class passengers, and also carried cargo. Her <a href="gross%20register%20ton">gross register ton</a>nage was 7700 (or 7,951) tons, and she was 450 feet (137 meters) long, powered by <a href="triple-expansion%20steam%20engine">triple-expansion steam engine</a>s, and capable of 14 knots, with an average cruise speed of 12 knots.
In August 1909, "Geelong" participated in a search for her <a href="sister%20ship">sister ship</a> "<a href="Waratah%20%28ship%29">Waratah</a>", which had disappeared without trace close to the <a href="South%20Africa">South Africa</a>n coast, and was thought to be disabled and drifting.
During <a href="World%20War%20I">World War I</a>, the <a href="Government%20of%20Australia">Government of Australia</a> leased "Geelong" for use as a <a href="troopship">troopship</a> to transport the <a href="First%20Australian%20Imperial%20Force">Australian Imperial Force</a> to the <a href="Middle%20East">Middle East</a> and <a href="Europe">Europe</a>. Designated HMAT A2 "Geelong", the ship departed on her first voyage as a troopship on 22 September 1914, carrying 440 soldiers from <a href="Melbourne">Melbourne</a>, Australia, consisting of the <a href="Australian%20Army">Australian Army</a>′s 3rd Field Artillery Brigade, the 3rd Field Company Engineers, and some members of the 12th Infantry Battalion. She proceeded to <a href="Hobart">Hobart</a>, Australia, where she picked up another 912 soldiers, consisting of the <a href="12th%20Battalion%20%28Australia%29">12th Infantry Battalion</a> and the 3rd Light Horse Regiment. She left Hobart, bound for <a href="Egypt">Egypt</a>, on 20 October 1914.
Her second outbound trooping voyage left <a href="Adelaide">Adelaide</a>, Australia, on 31 May 1915, transporting 1,264 soldiers of the <a href="27th%20Battalion%20%28Australia%29">27th Infantry Battalion</a> and the 7th Field Ambulance unit. She also picked up another 252 soldiers, who were reinforcements for various other units, from <a href="Fremantle">Fremantle</a>, Australia, on 7 June 1915.
Her final departure from Australia was on 18 November 1915, carrying 1,362 soldiers, including the <a href="32nd%20Battalion%20%28Australia%29">32nd Infantry Battalion</a> and some reinforcements for other units. Shortly after disembarking the men in Egypt, "Geelong" sank after a collision with , an <a href="British%20Admiralty">Admiralty</a> <a href="store%20ship">store ship</a>, in the <a href="Mediterranean%20Sea">Mediterranean Sea</a> near <a href="Alexandria">Alexandria</a>, <a href="Egypt">Egypt</a>, on 1 January 1916. There was no loss of life.
